metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: We tell stories to our coworkers and peers all the time — to persuade someone to support our project, to explain to an employee how he might improve, or to inspire a team that is facing challenges

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
It’s an essential skill, but what makes a compelling story in a business context? And how can you improve your ability to tell stories that persuade?

What the Experts Say.
In our information-saturated age, business leaders “won’t be heard unless they’re telling stories,” says Nick Morgan, author of Power Cues and president and founder of Public Words, a communications consulting firm

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “Facts and figures and all the rational things that we think are important in the business world actually don’t stick in our minds at all,” he says

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: But stories create “sticky” memories by attaching emotions to things that happen

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: That means leaders who can create and share good stories have a powerful advantage over others

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: And fortunately, everyone has the ability to become a better storyteller

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “We are programmed through our evolutionary biology to be both consumers and creators of story,” says Jonah Sachs, CEO of Free Range Studios and author of Winning the Story Wars

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“It certainly can be taught and learned.” Here’s how to use storytelling to your benefit.

Start with a message.
Every storytelling exercise should begin by asking: Who is my audience and what is the message I want to share with them? Each decision about your story should flow from those questions

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Sachs says that leaders should ask, “What is the core moral that I’m trying to implant in my team?” and “How can I boil that down to a compelling single statement?” For instance, if your team is behaving as if failure is not an option, you might decide to impart the message that failure is actually the grandfather of success

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Or if you are trying to convince senior leaders to take a risk by supporting your project, you could convey that most companies are built on taking smart chances

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
First settle on your ultimate message; then you can figure out the best way to illustrate it.

Mine your own experiences.
The best storytellers look to their own memories and life experiences for ways to illustrate their message

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: What events in your life make you believe in the idea you are trying to share? “Think of a moment in which your own failures led to success in your career, or a lesson that a parent or mentor imparted,” says Sachs

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “Any of these things can be interesting emotional entry points to a story.” There may be a tendency not to want to share personal details at work, but anecdotes that illustrate struggle, failure, and barriers overcome are what make leaders appear authentic and accessible

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“The key is to show your vulnerability,” says Morgan.

Don’t make yourself the hero.
That said, don’t make yourself the star of your own story

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “A story about your chauffeured car and having millions in stock options is not going to move your employees,” says Morgan

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: You can be a central figure, but the ultimate focus should be on people you know, lessons you’ve learned, or events you’ve witnessed

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: And whenever possible, you should endeavor to “make the audience or employees the hero,” says Morgan

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: It increases their engagement and willingness to buy in to your message

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “One of the main reasons we listen to stories is to create a deeper belief in ourselves,” says Sachs

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“But when the storyteller talks about how great they are, the audience shuts down.” The more you celebrate your own decisions, the less likely your audience will connect with you and your message.

Highlight a struggle.
A story without a challenge simply isn’t very interesting

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “Good storytellers understand that a story needs conflict,” says Morgan

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Is there a competitor that needs to be bested? A market challenge that needs to be overcome? A change-resistant industry that needs to be transformed? Don’t be afraid to suggest the road ahead will be difficult

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “We actually like to be told it’s going to be hard,” says Morgan

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “Smart leaders tell employees, ‘This is going to be tough

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: But if we all pull together and hang in there, we’ll achieve something amazing in the end.’” A well-crafted story embedded with that kind of a rallying cry means “you don’t have to demand change or effort,” says Sachs

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“People will become your partners in change,” because they want to be part of the journey.

Keep it simple.
Not every story you tell has to be a surprising, edge-of-your-seat epic

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Some of the most successful and memorable stories are relatively simple and straightforward

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Don’t let needless details to detract from your core message

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Work from the principle that “less is more.” One of the biggest mistakes you can make is “putting in too much detail of the wrong kind,” says Morgan

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Don’t tell your audience what day of the week it was, for instance, or what shoes you were wearing if it doesn’t advance the story in an artful way

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
But transporting your audience with a few interesting, well-placed details — how you felt, the expression on a face, the humble beginnings of a now-great company — can help immerse your listeners and drive home your message.

Practice makes perfect.
Storytelling is a “real art form” that requires repeated effort to get right, says Morgan

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Practice with friends, loved ones, and trusted colleagues to hone your message into the most effective and efficient story

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: And remember that the rewards can be immense

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “Stories are the original viral tool,” says Sachs

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“Once you tell a very compelling story, the first thing someone does is think, ‘Who can I can tell this story to?’ So, for the extra three minutes you spend encoding a leadership communication in a story, you’re going to see returns that last for months and maybe even years.”
    
Consider your audience — choose a framework and details that will best resonate with your listeners.
Identify the moral or message your want to impart.
Find inspiration in your life experiences.

Assume you don’t have storytelling chops — we all have it in us to tell memorable stories.
Give yourself the starring role.
Overwhelm your story with unnecessary details.

Case Study #1: Embed conflict to motivate and inspire.
Josh Linkner was worried his employees were becoming complacent

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Then the CEO of ePrize, a Detroit-based interactive promotions company, Linkner had seen his company become the dominant leader in the online promotions industry almost overnight

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: In the mid 2000s, “we had double and triple growth every year,” he says

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“I became worried that we would start clinging to our previous success instead of forging new success, and that our creativity would decline.”

“Greatness is often achieved in the face of adversity,” he says, “but we didn’t have a competitor to gun against.”

So he made up a fake nemesis

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: At an all-company meeting, he stood up and announced that there was a brash new competitor named Slither

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “I told everyone they were bigger than us, faster than us, and more profitable,” he says

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “Their investors had deeper pockets

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
Their footprint was better, and they were innovating at a pace I’d never seen.”

The story was greeted with chuckles around the room (it was obvious the company was a ruse), but the idea soon became embedded within ePrize’s culture

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
Executives kept reinforcing the Slither story with fake press releases about their competitor’s impressive quarterly earnings or infusions of capital, and soon the urge to best the imaginary rival began to drive improved performance.

“It inspired creativity,” Linkner says

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “In brainstorming sessions, we used Slither as the foil

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Instead of saying, ‘OK, guys, we have to reduce our production time

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: How are we going to do that?’ I would say, ‘The folks over at Slither just shaved two days out of their cycle time

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
How do you think they did it?’ The white boards filled with ideas.”

Case Study #2: Anchor the story in your personal experiences.
Vince Molinaro, managing director of the leadership practice at Knightsbridge Human Capital Solutions, Canada’s biggest HR advisory, tells clients he knows exactly when his career direction snapped into focus

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: It was at his first job out of college, with an organization that helped needy individuals get back on their feet

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Vince loved the mission but found the atmosphere uninspiring

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “Everyone just went through the motions,” he says

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“I remember thinking, ‘Is this it? Is this what working in the real world is like?’”

A senior manager named Zinta sensed that Vince wanted to have a bigger impact, and asked him to join several likeminded colleagues on a committee to make their workplace a more positive environment

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: They began to make subtle changes, and coworkers’ attitudes started to improve

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“I saw firsthand how a single manager can change the culture of a place,” he says.

Then Zinta was diagnosed with aggressive lung cancer

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: In her absence, the office culture began to revert back

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: On a visit to see Zinta in the hospital, Vince told her about the disappointing turn of events

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
She surprised him with a confession: Since she had never smoked and had no history of cancer in her family, she was convinced that her disease was a direct function of putting up with a toxic work environment for so long.

Shortly after, Zinta sent Vince a letter telling him he would be faced with an important choice throughout his life

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: He could allow the negative attitudes of others to influence his behavior, or pursue professional goals because of the sense of personal accomplishment they offered

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “In her time of need she reached out to me,” he says

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“She was a mentor to me even though she didn’t need to be.”

Two weeks later, Zinta passed away

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: But the letter changed Vince’s life, inspiring him to leave his job and start his own consulting business devoted to helping people be better leaders

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “I’ve seen the kind of climate and culture that a great leader can create,” he says

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“For the last 25 years, I’ve tried to emulate that.” He still has Zinta’s letter.

When Vince first began sharing this story with his leadership clients, he was taken aback by their reaction

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: “There was a connection they had to me that was really surprising, he says

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence:
“It’s like they got me in ways that I wasn’t able to directly communicate.”

“It also gets them thinking about their own story and the leaders that have influenced them

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: In my case, it was a great leader

metadata.author: Carolyn O'Hara
metadata.title: How to Tell a Great Story
metadata.sentence: Sometimes it’s the really bad ones you learn a lot from.” Whatever the case, he says, the power comes from sharing your story with the people you lead so they better understand what motivates you.
